Notes: very specific, targetted at agricultural crops in french

Alignment/connection to external concept: EBVs, Agrovoc, GEMET, EnvThes, GACS, AnaEE, EARTh, ENVO
Notes: Extensive thesaurus which contains a large number of general concepts used to categorise biodiversity research data (so these are categories of observable properties rather than observable properties per se). For examples, at the lower level we have concepts like e.g. "nitrogen cycle", "bioaccumulation", "microbial activity". However, importantly, these categories are linked to EBV classes.There are a few terms that I would qualify as observable property terms like e.g.  "plant height", "plant cover" (these are found in the grouping "Property / Parameter / Miscelleneous characteristics"). The ony reference to nitrogen is for "nitrogen cycle" (http://data.loterre.fr/ark:/67375/BLH-Q5J3P43B-Q). So this terminology would combine well with controlled vocabularies that are more specialised in describing the quantities, qualities, and objects measured or observed (i.e. "column header-type" vocabularies).
Comments from meeting 18/08/2020: fairly high level categories of observable properties or research objects in the field of terrestrial ecology. Some observable proerty terms but not many.

Notes: Contains terms for wheat traits and properties and environmental measurements related to soil properties, wind speed. Research object='wheat'
Comments from meeting 18/08/2020: wheat specific use case but importance for interoperability between terminologies dealing with similar concepts

terminology name: Minimal Information about any Sequence Ontology (MIxS) cryosphere extension

keywords: Oceanography; contamination; biogeochemistry; marine geology and geophysics; marine meteorology; biology; measurements in water; atmosphere; sediments; artifical experiment containers or interventions.

Notes: The BODC PUV is a controlled vocabulary for labelling variables in databases and data files in oceanography and related domains. It is a collection of unique and persistent identifiers attached to structurally logical labels and textual definitions. Semantic model  based on the conceptualisation of what constitutes a measurement and the atomisation into its constituent parts: a PROPERTY of an OBJECT in RELATION to a MATRIX by a METHOD.  Presentation: https://www.bodc.ac.uk/resources/vocabularies/parameter_codes/documents/BODC_P01_PUV_semantic_model_Aug19.pdf.  Github: https://github.com/nvs-vocabs/P01

Notes: Phytoplankton traits categorised into demographic traits and functional traits. Current content focuses on biomass (demographic trait) and morpho-functional traits in particular cell shape and cell size including carbon content. Terms for research object set to "no" because the research object is fixed by the specificity of the terminology target (phytoplankton). However we can discuss if the fact there is an extensive range of attributes related to further qualify the research object means that we should select "yes".
Comments from meeting 18/08/2020: phytoplankton specific use case but importance for interoperability between terminologies dealing with similar concepts

keywords: hydrology; physical oceanography; deep earth processes; aquatic chemistry; others
Alignment/connection to external concept: points to Wikipedia (and thus indirectly connected to other Wikimedia resources), mappings for CF names, SWEET available
Notes: SVO is primarily a "top"-level ontology focused on the creation of machine readable representations of scientific variables. The primary aim is to specify how phenomena and properties can be combined to create complex variable representations through design patterns. SVO does not focus on experimental/measurement methods and how they affect observations but rather represents "ideal" or "desired" variables. SVO has a populated lower ontology of domain-specific terms; however, SVO does not aim to define these terms -- rather, the long-term goal is to link these terms to persistent, external definitions. At the moment, many lower ontology terms are linked to Wikipedia and thus, indirectly, to Wikidata entries and the links to other resources made therein. SVO has a persistent IRI and is set up for content negotiation to provide html, xml, and ttl files as requested. SVO also provides a SPARQL endpoint. SVO is currently not registered any public repositories, although it should be added to ESIP COR within the next few months.

Reference data terminology that can be used across communities and stakeholders to synchronize conceptualization, to enable better understanding within and between communities and finally to stimulate tool building, such as for data services, supportive of the basic modelâ€™s use. We assume that this abstract data organization model will focus on common building blocks and their characteristics, along with relevant protocols.
